2.93.text:
Curious Droid presents America's
forgotten Concordes the planes that

8.30.text:
never flew. When we think of supersonic
passenger air travel

12.43.text: most people will think of concorde, the joint British French design plane which

17.27.text:
operated from 1976 until 2003 and up
until this day has been the only

24.16.text:
long-term supersonic passenger jet
service to operate anywhere in the world.

29.30.text:
What many people don't know is that in
the 60's and 70's there were

33.71.text:
three other competing designs from
United States and Russia. The Russian

38.57.text:
Tupolev Tu 144 was the first commercial
supersonic transport aircraft or SST

45.64.text:
which had its first flight two months
before concorde on the 31st of December

50.36.text:
1969, however after a crash at the Paris
Air Show in 1973 and another in 1978 it

58.41.text:
was grounded after just 55 flights,
although it has remained in service as a

63.73.text: research platform well into the 1990's. The other two American designs

68.89.text:
are less well known about because
despite a huge government backing and

73.60.text:
that supersonic transport was meant to
be the next big thing after the moon

77.71.text:
landings neither of the designs by
Boeing and Lockheed made it into the air.

82.42.text:
The story started in 1962 when the
British and French governments announced

87.50.text:
that they will jointly build a new
airliner that could travel at twice the

91.09.text: speed of sound and which would be called concorde. This was to be the most

95.21.text:
advanced civilian aircraft in the world
showing that European aircraft manufacturers could

100.39.text:
create the most leading edge designs
something that the Americans believed

104.91.text:
they were the best at. When President
John F Kennedy found out that Pan-Am

109.43.text:
wanted to buy Conchords he was so 
annoyed that he called at the Pan Am

113.62.text:
boss who told him that if there was an
American alternative he wouldn't have to

117.69.text:
go to Europe to buy the planes he wanted.
To meet this new challenge and to rescue

122.53.text:
American national pride President John F
Kennedy stated that

126.38.text:
America would build his own supersonic
transport aircraft and that it would be both

131.36.text:
bigger and faster than the European
design. Two designs one from Boeing and

137.12.text: another one from Lockheed were selected for further development and as an

140.49.text:
incentive the US government said it would
pay a 75 percent of the program's cost.

146.71.text: The lockheed L-2000 design was almost a scaled-up concorde intended to fly up to

153.18.text:
Mach 3 or 2,300 miles an hour while
carrying 278 passengers for a range of

161.59.text:
The development of smaller fighters like
French Mirage 3 and a russian MIG-21

166.39.text:
had already proven the Delta shape
wing similar concorde could easily go to

172.02.text:
Mach 2 and beyond and this was the
route

174.60.text:
lockheed chose. Boeing on the other hand
opted for a much more complex swing  wing

179.58.text:
design will be straight at low-speed
which would improve at takeoff and

183.83.text:
landing and then swing back to become a
delta wing as the speed increased.

188.05.text:
Boeings 2707 design were supposed to
be out fly at Mach 2.7 or 2,300 mph

195.21.text: and carry more than 270 passengers for  more

199.07.text:
than 4,200 miles. After much testing the
Boeing 2707 design was chosen as a

205.61.text:
winner on the 1st of January 1967.
Progress though was far from smooth.

211.16.text:
One of the main features at the 2707 was
meant to have was its ability to fly

215.75.text:
hundreds of miles an hours faster than
concorde but this being created huge

220.44.text:
implications for the plane.  Kit Mitchell
who was the principal scientific officer

224.93.text: at the Royal Aeronautical Establishment (RAE) in the 1960's also worked on

229.60.text:
Concorde. Kit said that the Boeing 2707's
main problem was but it was trying to

234.98.text:
do too much and so much of the
technology of it was required was still

239.09.text:
in its infancy. Military jets could fly
supersonic but even then it was only for

243.51.text:
a few minutes at a time and not for a
four-hour flight times like the airliners

247.17.text:
expected to. The technology required to
do this in the 1960's was

251.49.text: almost as much of a challenge

253.26.text:
are sending a man to the moon. Concorde
got around many of these issues because

257.17.text: even though it flew at Mach 2,  it wasn't so far as to require exotic materials and brand new

263.66.text: untested designs. Concorde was effectively the next step up from the V- Bombers

268.90.text:
which the British had already developed.
One of the biggest issues was the extra

273.37.text: speed that was required. Concorde flow at Mach 2 or 1350 mph

279.82.text:
the Boeing was meant to fly 650 miles an
hour faster. Due to compression of the

286.71.text:
many of the fuselage parts on Concorde 
were heated to over 100C

290.25.text: and the nose tip alone reached a 127C

294.94.text: when cruising at Mach 2. The body of concorde was

299.48.text:
300mm or approximately one
foot longer at supersonic speeds than it

305.85.text:
was when it was on the ground. This
expansion and contraction of the body

310.49.text:
could lead to metal fatigue if not
carefully maintained. It also meant that

314.90.text:
concorde had a relatively short airframe
life of 45,000 hours compared to 100,000 hours for

321.40.text:
a Boeing 747 and that would have an
impact on the overall running costs for

326.51.text:
the airlines. Everything from the window
seals to be electrical wiring had to be

331.42.text:
designed for a "hot" plane. Because the
Boeing was going to travel so much

335.64.text:
faster they couldn't use aluminium but
instead the plane will be made from

340.65.text: titanium which would also push up costs dramatically. Also the swing wing design which worked

346.49.text:
well on smaller two seater fighters when
scaled up to a 300 seater

350.74.text:
airliner, needed to be so big and strong
that it made the plane too heavy to be

355.45.text: viable. so after huge amount of work

357.81.text:
the designers had to drop the swing wing
design and returned to the drawing board

362.04.text:
and go back to the delta wing design of
the lockheed and Concorde. By the time

367.10.text:
the Concorde was in flight testing and
the Boeing was still in the design phase

371.01.text:
people had become all too aware of a
sonic boom created by these planes and

376.21.text:
it was going to be too much for problem
and as such

379.44.text:
supersonic flight over land was banned
in most countries. This meant that the

384.17.text:
only viable routes were over the Atlantic
from the east coast of the United States

388.75.text:
to the west coast in Europe. With these
limited routes the amount of seats that

393.75.text:
could  be sold was greatly reduced and
the prospect of supersonic flight was

398.28.text:
dealt a huge blow. But what really
finished the Boeing end the Concorde In

402.64.text:
end, even before the one and only crash
of the Air France Concorde in 2000 was

408.20.text:
the cost of the fuel and traveling at
supersonic speed uses a lot of it.

413.10.text:
With the inefficiency of jet engines at low
speeds concorde burned two tons of fuel

418.64.text:
just taxiing to the runway and the
Boeing also going to be a very hungry

424.52.text:
plane to operate. The thinking at the
time was that if you could fly to your

429.03.text:
destination in half the time, then you
could do twice as many journeys and

433.64.text:
charge a premium, so fuel efficiency was
not a top priority. When the supersonic

438.49.text: designs were created in the 1960's fuel was cheap but by the time

442.44.text:
in 1970's arrived when they
were due to be coming into service the

446.24.text:
price had risen together with the
recession of 1971 and government

450.41.text:
cutbacks, it ended up terminating the
Boeing 2707 project. The two Boeing

455.63.text:
prototypes were never finished and with
both the loss of a government contracts

459.81.text:
and recession of the civilian
aviation market, Boeing ended up cutting

463.96.text: over 60,000 jobs. The Boeing 2707 became known as the plane almost ate Seattle

471.72.text:
as a result of the mass layoffs and with
so many people moving away from the city

476.58.text:
in search of work, a billboard was
erected near Sea-Tac airport in 1971

482.00.text:
that read the "Will the last person leaving
Seattle - turn out the lights".

485.27.text:
Ironically the
plane that saved Boeing from going

489.83.text:
bankrupt was originally thought of as
just a stopgap measure while supersonic

494.65.text:
planes took over air travel. That
plane was the Boeing 747 jumbo jet.

499.89.text:
Despite the project's failure Boeing 
learned a lot from the 2707 and much of

505.67.text:
it made its way into other experimental
vehicles but the aerospace giant built

510.35.text:
in the following decade including some
of the unmanned vehicles built in recent

514.62.text:
years. The supercritical wing designed to
tweak that came out to be 2707 project and is

520.37.text:
now routinely used on modern airliners
to limit shock waves and reduce drag.

525.11.text:
While lockheed's ill-fated L-2000
design will also live on thanks to a

530.23.text: collaboration between NASA and lockheed to fly an experimental demonstrator to

535.24.text:
research the future of supersonic
aircraft, so maybe in years to come

540.57.text:
US built supersonic airliner will
finally take to the skies. Thanks for

549.38.text:
watching and I hope you enjoyed the
video, if you did then don't forget

552.54.text:
please thumbs up and subscribe for more
and if you have any ideas for videos you

556.45.text:
like to see please let us know in the
